Award.AwardTitle: Automorphic forms, L-functions and the relative trace formula
Award.AbstractNarration:
The relative trace formula is an important tool in the study of automorphic forms and the Langlands program. Jacquet invented the relative trace formula to study period integrals of automorphic forms, in particular, to establish criteria for certain cases of functoriality in terms of non-vanishing of periods. More recently, work has been done in some cases relating the value of the period explicitly to special values of L-functions. The importance of the relative trace formula is widely recognized and the field is far from exhausted. The PI plans on generalizing to higher rank groups a result of Waldspurger and Jacquet linking L-values with period integrals, extending work of hers on a subconvex bound and generalizing results of hers on an average L-value formula to higher degree L-functions where much less is known. In addition, she will continue her work in computing statistics for curves over finite fields by looking at the distribution of the zeros of the zeta functions of a family of Artin-Schreier curves defined over a finite field as the genus of the family increases.

The PI's proposal includes a plan to mentor and conduct research with undergraduate students at The City College of New York. This institution has a diverse student body consisting of large numbers of traditionally underrepresented groups, in terms of race, ethnicity and socio-economic background. In addition the PI will continue her work mentoring women in mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported under this grant concerns projects in number theory that focus on problems in automorphic forms and curves over finite fields. The trace formula is an important tool in number theory for the study of automorphic forms and the Langlands program. Jacquet invented the relative trace formula to study period integrals of automorphic forms, in particular, to establish criteria for certain cases of functoriality in terms of non-vanishing of periods. More recently, work has been done in some cases relating the value of the period explicitly to special values of L-functions. The importance of the relative trace formula is widely recognized and the field is far from exhausted. The PI worked on this topic and its arithmetic applications to automorphic forms and the central values of L-functions.

A second research area involves the explicit construction of Ramanujan bigraphs using automorphic representation theory. These explicit constructions are of interest even to researchers outside of number theory because of the wide-ranging applications of Ramanujan graphs and bigraphs. 

The PI also studied curves over finite fields as part of this project. By the philosophy of Katz and Sarnak, for curves of fixed genus over a field with q elements, as q goes to infinity, the trace of the Frobenius should be distributed as the trace of a certain ensemble of unitary matrices, determined by the monodromy group of the family of curves. The proposer completed several projects which address what happens when the field is fixed and the genus grows. 

In addition to the research projects described above, this grant also supported many activities that have a broader impact on society. The PI mentored undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in original research projects. The PI also mentored and improved the network of women in mathematics and science through her work co-organizing an international research conference for women number theorists and the creation of two student chapters of the Association for Women in Mathematics. In addition the PI worked on outreach to public high school math teachers and students through her involvement with Math for America and NYC public high school teachers. Finally, the PI co-organized a number theory research seminar at the CUNY Graduate Center and made a particular effort to recruit as speakers junior mathematicians and those from underrepresented groups.
